issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for SealSaloon: the problem statement and UML explicitly show/describe a constructor SealSaloon(String) that takes a saloon name (for identification), but both the provided template usage (Main) and the solution implement/use a no-argument constructor SealSaloon(). This mismatch can confuse students about which constructor signature to implement and whether to store a saloon name as a field.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the constructor signature across artifacts. Either: (A) Update the template, Main, and solution to provide and use SealSaloon(String name) (and store the name with an appropriate getter), or (B) Update the problem statement and UML to require a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()) and remove the statement that the constructor takes a saloon name. Choose the option that matches intended tests; if tests/Main expect no-arg, prefer (B) to avoid forcing students to change example usage.

issues.description: Constructor signature mismatch for SealSaloon: the problem statement (UML and textual description) requires a constructor SealSaloon(String) that accepts a saloon name, but both the provided template Main and the reference solution use / instantiate a no-argument constructor SealSaloon(). This inconsistency can confuse students about the required API (they may implement a constructor with a String parameter per the spec or expect a name field/getter that the solution does not provide).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the API consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution and template to provide a constructor SealSaloon(String name) (store the name in a private field and add a getName() getter), and update calls in Main to pass a name; or (B) update the problem statement/UML to specify a no-argument constructor SealSaloon() if no saloon name is required. Option A is preferred to match the current problem text that explicitly requires a named constructor.
